“Dmitri Prokofitch Razumihin,” she said, introducing him to Luzhin. 

“I had the pleasure … yesterday,” Pyotr Petrovitch muttered, glaring at Razumihin. 

Silence fell. Raskolnikov remained mute. Avdotya Romanovna hesitated to speak. 

Pulcheria Alexandrovna broke the stillness. “Marfa Petrovna is dead. Have you heard?”

“I heard. Arkady Ivanovitch Svidrigaïlov left for Petersburg after the funeral.”

“Here?” Dounia’s eyes widened. 

“Yes, and not without purpose,” Pyotr Petrovitch replied coldly.

“Will he leave Dounia in peace?” Pulcheria cried. 

The tension thickened. Fear lingered in the air.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Pyotr Petrovitch's polite demeanor masks his discomfort and hostility towards Razumihin as they discuss the recent death of Marfa Petrovna and the arrival of Svidrigaïlov in Petersburg.
